April 9, 1989: Fiction
THE SATANIC VERSES, by Salman Rushdie. (Viking, $19.95.) Two emigres from
Bombay enact the roles of good and evil in contemporary London.
STAR, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $19.95.) The crossed paths of a man and a
woman who are destined for stardom in different professions.
A PRAYER FOR OWEN MEANY, by John Irving. (Morrow, $19.95.) A schoolboy
who accidentally killed the mother of his best friend turns into a prophet with a
message for our times.
THE EDGE, by Dick Francis. (Putnam, $18.95.) Murder and mayhem on a luxury
trans-Canadian train trip.
BILLY BATHGATE, by E. L. Doctorow. (Random House, $19.95.) The life of the
1930's gangster Dutch Schultz, as seen by a bright youth from the Bronx.
THE LONG DARK TEA-TIME OF THE SOUL, by Douglas Adams. (Simon &
Schuster, $17.95.) The detective of ''The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy''
pursues the meaning of an explosion at an airport.
CAT'S EYE, by Margaret Atwood. (Doubleday, $18.95.) A woman's visit to her
native Toronto leads her to reflect on the changes time has wrought.
THE FORTUNE, by Michael Korda. (Summit, $19.95.) A young woman's ill-fated
romance with the head of America's richest family.
THE CARDINAL OF THE KREMLIN, by Tom Clancy. (Putnam, $19.95.) The
C.I.A.'s Jack Ryan races to the rescue of an American secret agent.
THE SANDS OF TIME, by Sidney Sheldon. (Morrow, $19.95.) Four nuns become
pawns in a struggle between the Spanish Army and Basque separatists.
MIDNIGHT, by Dean R. Koontz. (Putnam, $19.95.) Inexplicable deaths and
strange horrors take over a once idyllic California town.
WE ARE STILL MARRIED, by Garrison Keillor. (Viking, $18.95.) Stories, poems
and satirical pieces, mostly reflecting life in Minnesota during the Reagan era.
MORNING GLORY, by LaVyrle Spencer. (Putnam, $14.95.) A young widow in a
sleepy Georgia town finds true love during World War II.
BLACK SAND, by William J. Caunitz. (Crown, $18.95.) A New York cop joins a
Greek policeman in the deadly pursuit of a stolen ancient artifact.
THE JOY LUCK CLUB, by Amy Tan. (Putnam, $18.95.) The tensions and cultural
bonds shared by Chinese-American women and their immigrant mothers.
April 9, 1989
Non-Fiction
ALL I REALLY NEED TO KNOW I LEARNED IN KINDERGARTEN, by Robert
Fulghum. (Villard, $15.95.) Inspirational essays.
A BRIEF HISTORY OF TIME, by Stephen W. Hawking. (Bantam, $18.95.) A
scientist reviews efforts to create a unified theory of the universe.
BLIND FAITH, by Joe McGinniss. (Putnam, $21.95.) The family tragedy that came
to light after the 1984 murder of a Toms River, N.J., woman.
THE BLOODING, by Joseph Wambaugh. (Morrow, $18.95.) The murder of two
teen-age girls in an English village is solved through genetic clues.
INNUMERACY, by John Allen Paulos. (Hill & Wang, $16.95.) Americans'
mathematical illiteracy and its consequences for our culture.
LEGENDS, LIES, AND CHERISHED MYTHS OF AMERICAN HISTORY, by
Richard Shenkman. (Morrow, $15.95.) An expose of tall tales.
GRACIE, by George Burns. (Putnam, $16.95.) The life of the comedian Gracie
Allen, recalled by her widower and show business partner.
“FUNNY, YOU DON'T LOOK LIKE A GRANDMOTHER,'' by Lois Wyse. (Crown,
$12.95.) An advertising woman's reflections on her role as the grandparent of
eight.
THE LAST LION, by William Manchester. (Little, Brown, $24.95.) The second
volume of a biography of Winston Churchill, covering the years 1932-40.
THE BOY WHO COULDN'T STOP WASHING, by Judith L. Rapoport. (Dutton,
$17.95.) A psychiatrist's account of the symptoms and treatment of an obsessive-
compulsive disorder.
SECOND CHANCES, by Judith S. Wallerstein and Sandra Blakeslee. (Ticknor &
Fields, $19.95.) A study of how divorce affects men, women and children during
the following decade.
“WHAT DO YOU CARE WHAT OTHER PEOPLE THINK?'' by Richard P.
Feynman with Ralph Leighton. (Norton, $17.95.) Memoirs of the Nobel Prize-
winning physicist.
THE FIRST SALUTE, by Barbara W. Tuchman. (Knopf, $22.95.) A historian's view
of the American Revolution.
RICHARD BURTON, by Melvyn Bragg. (Little, Brown, $22.95.) The professional
and private life of the distinguished actor.
